_**Rise of the Guardians**_ is a 2012 American [3D](/wiki/3D_film "3D film")
[computer-animated](/wiki/Computer-animated_film "Computer-animated film")
[fantasy film](/wiki/Fantasy_film "Fantasy film") based on [William
Joyce](/wiki/William_Joyce_\(writer\) "William Joyce \(writer\)")'s _The
Guardians of Childhood_ book series and _The Man in the Moon_ short film by
Joyce and [Reel FX Creative Studios](/wiki/Reel_FX_Creative_Studios "Reel FX
Creative Studios"). [Peter Ramsey](/wiki/Peter_Ramsey "Peter Ramsey") directed
the film, while Joyce and [Guillermo del Toro](/wiki/Guillermo_del_Toro
"Guillermo del Toro") were executive producers with voice acting by [Chris
Pine](/wiki/Chris_Pine "Chris Pine"), [Alec Baldwin](/wiki/Alec_Baldwin "Alec
Baldwin"), [Hugh Jackman](/wiki/Hugh_Jackman "Hugh Jackman"), [Isla
Fisher](/wiki/Isla_Fisher "Isla Fisher"), and [Jude Law](/wiki/Jude_Law "Jude
Law"). Produced by [DreamWorks Animation](/wiki/DreamWorks_Animation
"DreamWorks Animation") and distributed by [Paramount
Pictures](/wiki/Paramount_Pictures "Paramount Pictures"),1 it was released on
November 21, 2012.

Set about 300 years after the book series, the film tells a story about
Guardians [Santa Claus](/wiki/Santa_Claus "Santa Claus"), the [Tooth
Fairy](/wiki/Tooth_fairy "Tooth fairy"), the [Easter Bunny](/wiki/Easter_Bunny
"Easter Bunny"), and the [Sandman](/wiki/Sandman "Sandman"), who enlist [Jack
Frost](/wiki/Jack_Frost "Jack Frost") to stop [Pitch Black](/wiki/Bogeyman
"Bogeyman") from engulfing the world in darkness. The film was nominated for
the [Golden Globe Award for Best Animated Feature
Film](/wiki/Golden_Globe_Award_for_Best_Animated_Feature_Film "Golden Globe
Award for Best Animated Feature Film").[5] This was the last DreamWorks
Animation film to be distributed by Paramount Pictures.[6]

## Plot[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Rise_of_the_Guardians&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Plot")]

[Jack Frost](/wiki/Jack_Frost "Jack Frost") awakens from a frozen pond with
[amnesia](/wiki/Amnesia "Amnesia"). Upon realizing no one can see or hear him,
he disappears. Three hundred years later, Jack, as the young Spirit of Winter,
enjoys delivering snow days to school kids, but resents that they do not
believe in him. At the [North Pole](/wiki/North_Pole "North Pole"), the [Man
in the Moon](/wiki/Man_in_the_Moon "Man in the Moon") warns [Nicholas St.
North](/wiki/Santa_Claus "Santa Claus") that [Pitch Black](/wiki/Bogeyman
"Bogeyman") is threatening the children of the world with his nightmares. He
calls [E. Aster Bunnymund](/wiki/Easter_Bunny "Easter Bunny"),
[Sandy](/wiki/Sandman "Sandman"), and [Tooth](/wiki/Tooth_Fairy "Tooth
Fairy"), to arms. They are then told that Jack Frost has been chosen to be a
new Guardian.

Visiting Tooth's world, Jack learns that each and every [baby
tooth](/wiki/Baby_teeth "Baby teeth") contains childhood memories of the
children who lost it, Jack's teeth included. However, Pitch raids Tooth's
home, kidnapping all of her subordinate tooth fairies except Baby Tooth and
stealing all the teeth, thus preventing Tooth from sharing Jack's memories and
weakening children's belief in Tooth. In order to thwart Pitch's plan, the
group decides to collect children's teeth. During their journey, a quarrel
between North and Bunnymund awakens a boy, Jamie. Since he still believes, he
can see everybody except for Jack. Pitch's nightmares then attack, provoking
Sandy as the Guardian of Dreams. Jack tries to intervene, but Sandy is
overwhelmed and killed by Pitch.

As Easter approaches, the dejected Guardians gather in Bunnymund's home. With
the unexpected aid of Jamie's little sister, Sophie, they begin the process of
painting eggs for Easter. After Jack takes Sophie home, he is lured to Pitch's
lair by a voice. Pitch taunts him with his memories and fear of non-belief,
distracting him long enough for Pitch to destroy the eggs, causing children to
stop believing in Easter and Bunnymund. Losing his trust in the Guardians,
Jack isolates himself in Antarctica, where Pitch tries to convince him to join
his side. When Jack refuses, Pitch threatens to kill Baby Tooth unless Jack
gives him his staff, the source of his magic. He agrees, but Pitch breaks
Jack's staff and throws him down a chasm. Unlocking his memories, he learns
that he was a mortal teenager who fell into ice while saving his younger
sister. Inspired, Jack repairs his staff and returns to the lair to rescue the
kidnapped baby fairies.

In New York Due to Pitch, every child in the world except Jamie disbelieves,
drastically weakening the Guardians. Finding Jamie's belief wavering, Jack
makes it snow in his room, renewing Jamie's belief and letting him see Jack.
Jack and Jamie gather the boy's friends, whose renewed belief bolsters their
fight against Pitch. Pitch threatens them, but their dreams prove stronger
than his nightmares, resulting in Sandy's resurrection. Defeated and
disbelieved in, Pitch tries to retreat, but his nightmares, sensing his own
fears, turn on him and trap him in his lair. Afterward, Jamie and his friends
bid goodbye to the Guardians as Jack accepts his place as the Guardian of Fun.

## Cast[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Rise_of_the_Guardians&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Cast")]

  * [Chris Pine](/wiki/Chris_Pine "Chris Pine") as [Jack Frost](/wiki/Jack_Frost "Jack Frost"), the spirit of winter.[7] Jack Frost is a teenage hellion who enjoys creating mischief and has no interest in being bound by rules or obligations; he just wants to use his staff to spread his winter magic for the sake of fun, but also wants to be believed in. At the end of the film, Jack became the Guardian of Fun. While he cannot fly, per se, he can be carried on currents of wind, allowing him to span great distances.
  * [Alec Baldwin](/wiki/Alec_Baldwin "Alec Baldwin") as Nicholas St. North ([Santa Claus](/wiki/Santa_Claus "Santa Claus")), the leader of the guardians,[7] and the Guardian of Wonder. He lives at the [North Pole](/wiki/North_Pole "North Pole") in the Ice Castle and is served by loyal North Pole natives, the [Yetis](/wiki/Yeti "Yeti") (who built the castle and workshop) and the [Christmas Elves](/wiki/Christmas_elf "Christmas elf"). He carries a [Russian](/wiki/Russian_people "Russian people") accent/culture persona.[8]
  * [Hugh Jackman](/wiki/Hugh_Jackman "Hugh Jackman") as E. Aster Bunnymund ([Easter Bunny](/wiki/Easter_Bunny "Easter Bunny")), the fabled keeper and bringer of [Easter](/wiki/Easter "Easter") eggs and the Guardian of Hope. He has an [Australian](/wiki/Australian "Australian") accent.[7]
  * [Isla Fisher](/wiki/Isla_Fisher "Isla Fisher") as Tooth ([Tooth Fairy](/wiki/Tooth_fairy "Tooth fairy")), the mythical tooth collector and the Guardian of Memories.[7] Tooth is part [human](/wiki/Human "Human") and part [hummingbird](/wiki/Hummingbird "Hummingbird"). Assisted by mini fairies that are split-off extensions of herself, she collects the children's teeth, which hold their most precious memories. Tooth stores them in her palace and returns memories when they are needed the most.[9] She seems to have a crush on Jack, (or more acurately, his pure white teeth).
  * [Jude Law](/wiki/Jude_Law "Jude Law") as Pitch Black ([The Boogeyman](/wiki/Bogeyman "Bogeyman")), the essence of fear and the Nightmare King.[7]
  * [Dakota Goyo](/wiki/Dakota_Goyo "Dakota Goyo") as Jamie Bennett, a child who has not given up on believing in the Guardians.[10]
  * Sandy ([The Sandman](/wiki/Sandman "Sandman")), the Guardian of Dreams is the oldest of the Guardians[11] and the first Guardian chosen by Man in the Moon.[12] He does not speak, but communicates through sand images that he conjures above his head.[13]
  * Georgie Grieve as Sophie Bennett, Jamie's little sister
  * Dominique Grund as Cupcake
  * Olivia Mattingly as Pippa

##
Production[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Rise_of_the_Guardians&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Production")]

In 2005, [William Joyce](/wiki/William_Joyce_\(writer\) "William Joyce
\(writer\)") and [Reel FX](/wiki/Reel_FX_Creative_Studios "Reel FX Creative
Studios") launched a joint venture, Aimesworth Amusements,[14] to produce CG-
animated feature films,[15] one of which was set to be _The Guardians of
Childhood_ , based on Joyce's idea.[16] The film was not realized, but they
did create a short animated film, _The Man in the Moon_ , directed by Joyce,
which introduced the Guardians idea,[16] and served as an inspiration for the
film.[2]

Early in 2008, Joyce sold the film rights to DreamWorks Animation,[17] after
the studio assured him it would respect his vision for the characters and that
he would be involved with the creative process.[18] In November 2009, it was
revealed that DreamWorks had hired Peter Ramsey to make his feature debut as
director of what was then titled _The Guardians_ , and
[playwright](/wiki/Playwright "Playwright") [David Lindsay-
Abaire](/wiki/David_Lindsay-Abaire "David Lindsay-Abaire") to script.[19]
Joyce acted as a co-director for the first few years, but left this position
after the death of his daughter Mary Katherine,[17] who died of a brain
tumor.[18] Joyce continued to assist as an executive producer, while Ramsey
took over full directing, making him the first [African
American](/wiki/African_American "African American") to direct a big-budget CG
animated film.[20] As with some previous DreamWorks films, [Guillermo del
Toro](/wiki/Guillermo_del_Toro "Guillermo del Toro") came on board as an
executive producer. Present almost from the beginning,[21] he was able to help
shape the story, character design, theme and structure of the film.[22] He
said he was proud that the filmmakers were making parts of the film "dark and
moody and poetic," and expressed hope this might "set a different tone for
family movies, for entertainment movies."[21] The final title, _Rise of the
Guardians_ was announced in early 2011, along with the first cast.[7]

[Roger Deakins](/wiki/Roger_Deakins "Roger Deakins"), the cinematographer who
had already worked on the previous DreamWorks' film, _[How to Train Your
Dragon](/wiki/How_to_Train_Your_Dragon_\(film\) "How to Train Your Dragon
\(film\)")_ , advised on the lighting to achieve its real look. He selected
photographic references for color keys, and during the production gave notes
on contrast, saturation, depth of field and light intensity.[23] The film
contains a lot of special effects, particularly the volumetric particles for
depicting Sandman and Pitch.[24] For this, DreamWorks Animation developed
OpenVDB, a more efficient tool and format for manipulating and storing volume
data, like smoke and other amorphous materials. OpenVDB had been already used
on _[Puss in Boots](/wiki/Puss_in_Boots_\(2011_film\) "Puss in Boots \(2011
film\)")_ and _[Madagascar 3: Europe's Most
Wanted](/wiki/Madagascar_3:_Europe%27s_Most_Wanted "Madagascar 3: Europe's
Most Wanted")_, and was released in August 2012 for free as an open-source
project with a hope to become an industry standard.[25]

Although the film is based on the Joyce's book series, it contains differences
from the books. The book series, begun in 2011, explains the origins of the
characters, while the film takes place about 300 years after the books, and
shows how the characters function in present time. Joyce explained, "Because I
don't want people to read the book and then go see the movie and go, 'Oh, I
like the book better,' and I also didn't want them to know what happens in the
movie. And I also knew that during the progress of film production, a lot of
things can change. So I wanted to have a sort of distance, so we were able to
invoke the books and use them to help us figure out the world of the movie,
but I didn't want them to be openly competitive to each other."[17] The idea
for the Guardians came from Joyce's daughter, who asked him "if he thought
Santa Claus had ever met the Easter Bunny." The film includes a dedication to
her,[18] as well a song, "Still Dream," sung over the end credits.[26]

Originally, the film was set to be released on November 2, 2012, but
DreamWorks Animation pushed the film to November 21, 2012 to avoid competition
with [Pixar](/wiki/Pixar "Pixar")'s upcoming film _[Monsters
University](/wiki/Monsters_University "Monsters University")_ , which in turn
had been pushed to November 2, 2012 to avoid competition with _[The Twilight
Saga: Breaking Dawn – Part
2](/wiki/The_Twilight_Saga:_Breaking_Dawn_%E2%80%93_Part_2 "The Twilight Saga:
Breaking Dawn – Part 2")_.[27] _Monsters University_ was then pushed to June
21, 2013, with [Disney's](/wiki/Walt_Disney_Animation_Studios "Walt Disney
Animation Studios") _[Wreck-It Ralph](/wiki/Wreck-It_Ralph "Wreck-It Ralph")_
taking its place.[28]

##
Soundtrack[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Rise_of_the_Guardians&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Soundtrack")]

French composer [Alexandre Desplat](/wiki/Alexandre_Desplat "Alexandre
Desplat") composed the original music for the film, which was released on
November 13, 2012 by [Varèse Sarabande](/wiki/Var%C3%A8se_Sarabande "Varèse
Sarabande"). The [score](/wiki/Film_score "Film score") was recorded in London
at [Abbey Road Studios](/wiki/Abbey_Road_Studios "Abbey Road Studios") and
[Air Studios](/wiki/Associated_Independent_Recording "Associated Independent
Recording"), and performed by the [London Symphony
Orchestra](/wiki/London_Symphony_Orchestra "London Symphony Orchestra"), with
a choral contribution by [London Voices](/wiki/London_Voices "London Voices").
[David Lindsay-Abaire](/wiki/David_Lindsay-Abaire "David Lindsay-Abaire")
wrote the lyrics for the end-credit song, "Still Dream," which was performed
by soprano [Renée Fleming](/wiki/Ren%C3%A9e_Fleming "Renée Fleming").[29]
Stravinsky's Firebird Suite can also be heard during the scene where North
first appears. This film marks the first time that a DreamWorks Animation film
has not been composed by [Hans Zimmer](/wiki/Hans_Zimmer "Hans Zimmer") or a
member of his [Remote Control Productions](/wiki/Remote_Control_Productions
"Remote Control Productions") family of composers (mainly [John
Powell](/wiki/John_Powell_\(film_composer\) "John Powell \(film composer\)"),
[Henry Jackman](/wiki/Henry_Jackman "Henry Jackman"), [Harry Gregson-
Williams](/wiki/Harry_Gregson-Williams "Harry Gregson-Williams") or his
brother [Rupert Gregson-Williams](/wiki/Rupert_Gregson-Williams "Rupert
Gregson-Williams")).

##
Release[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Rise_of_the_Guardians&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Release")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/Rise_of_the_Guardians%2C_The_Mill_Valley_Film_Festival_premiere.jpg/220px-
Rise_of_the_Guardians%2C_The_Mill_Valley_Film_Festival_premiere.jpg)](/wiki/File:Rise_of_the_Guardians,_The_Mill_Valley_Film_Festival_premiere.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Rise_of_the_Guardians,_The_Mill_Valley_Film_Festival_premiere.jpg
"Enlarge")

_Rise of the Guardians_ premiere at the [Mill Valley Film
Festival](/wiki/Mill_Valley_Film_Festival "Mill Valley Film Festival"):
Christina Steinberg, producer; Peter Ramsey, director; [Jeffrey
Katzenberg](/wiki/Jeffrey_Katzenberg "Jeffrey Katzenberg"), DreamWorks
Animation's CEO; [Nancy Bernstein](/wiki/Nancy_Bernstein "Nancy Bernstein"),
producer; [Bill Damaschke](/wiki/Bill_Damaschke "Bill Damaschke"), DreamWorks
Animation's Chief Creative Officer

_Rise of the Guardians_ had its premiere on October 10, 2012, at [The Mill
Valley Film Festival](/wiki/Mill_Valley_Film_Festival "Mill Valley Film
Festival") in [Mill Valley, California](/wiki/Mill_Valley,_California "Mill
Valley, California"),[1] followed by the international premiere at The
[International Rome Film Festival](/wiki/Rome_Film_Festival "Rome Film
Festival") on November 13, 2012.[31][32] Under distribution by [Paramount
Pictures](/wiki/Paramount_Pictures "Paramount Pictures"), the film was
released on November 21, 2012, in [American](/wiki/United_States "United
States") theaters.[27] Digitally re-mastered into [IMAX 3D](/wiki/IMAX#IMAX_3D
"IMAX"), it was shown in limited international and domestic IMAX theaters.[33]
It was the second film released in the firm
[Barco](/wiki/Barco_\(manufacturer\) "Barco \(manufacturer\)")'s [Auro
11.1](/wiki/Auro_11.1 "Auro 11.1") 3D audio format, after _[Red
Tails](/wiki/Red_Tails "Red Tails")_.[34] The film was also shown in [Dolby
Atmos](/wiki/Dolby_Atmos "Dolby Atmos"), a surround sound technology
introduced in 2012.[35] _Rise of the Guardians_ was the last DreamWorks
Animation film distributed by Paramount, as DreamWorks has signed a five-year
distribution deal with [20th Century Fox](/wiki/20th_Century_Fox "20th Century
Fox"), which started in 2013 with _[The Croods](/wiki/The_Croods "The
Croods")_.[6]

### Home
media[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Rise_of_the_Guardians&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Home media")]

_Rise of the Guardians_ was released on [Blu-ray Disc](/wiki/Blu-ray "Blu-
ray") (2D and 3D) and [DVD](/wiki/DVD "DVD") on March 12, 2013.[36]

That was the last DreamWorks Animation home media release to be distributed by
[Paramount Home Entertainment](/wiki/Paramount_Home_Entertainment "Paramount
Home Entertainment"), since 20th Century Fox announced its distribution
agreement with DreamWorks Animation a few months before the theatrical
release.[6] The film was more successful at home media sales than at the box
office, having at the end of the second quarter of 2013 "the highest box
office to DVD conversion ratio among major releases."[37] In the first quarter
of 2013, it sold 3.2 million home entertainment units worldwide,[38] and in
the second quarter 0.9 million units, for a total of 4.1 million units.[39] As
of August 2013, 2 million DVDs were sold domestically.[40]

It was re-released on DVD on November 5, 2013 and comes with a wind-up
marching elf toy.[41]

##
Reception[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Rise_of_the_Guardians&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Reception")]

### Critical
response[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Rise_of_the_Guardians&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Critical response")]

Based on 148 reviews, the film holds a rating of 74% on review aggregator
[Rotten Tomatoes](/wiki/Rotten_Tomatoes "Rotten Tomatoes"), with an average
rating of 6.5/10, based on 151 reviews. The website's critical consensus
reads: "A sort of _[Avengers](/wiki/The_Avengers_\(2012_film\) "The Avengers
\(2012 film\)")_ for the elementary school set, _Rise of the Guardians_ is
wonderfully animated and briskly paced, but it's only so-so in the
storytelling department."[42] Another review aggregator,
[Metacritic](/wiki/Metacritic "Metacritic"), which assigns a
[normalized](/wiki/Normalization_\(statistics\) "Normalization
\(statistics\)") rating out of 100 top reviews from mainstream critics,
calculated a score of 57 based on 34 reviews, or "Mixed or average."[43] The
film earned an "A" from audiences polled by [CinemaScore](/wiki/CinemaScore
"CinemaScore").[44]

Carrie Rickey of _[The Philadelphia Inquirer](/wiki/The_Philadelphia_Inquirer
"The Philadelphia Inquirer")_ gave the film three-and-a-half out of four stars
and found the film's characters to have "a primal familiarity, as though they
were developed by a tag team of [Maurice Sendak](/wiki/Maurice_Sendak "Maurice
Sendak") and [Walt Disney](/wiki/Walt_Disney "Walt Disney")."[45] Olly
Richards of _[Empire](/wiki/Empire_\(film_magazine\) "Empire \(film
magazine\)")_ wrote, "It's gorgeously designed, deftly written and frequently
laugh-out-loud funny. For child or adult, this is a fantasy to get lost
in."[46] _[The Washington Post](/wiki/The_Washington_Post "The Washington
Post")_ 's Michael O'Sullivan also gave the film a positive review and said,
"Thoughts become things. That's the message of _Rise of the Guardians_ , a
charming if slightly dark and cobwebbed animated feature about how believing
in something makes it real, or real enough."[47] [Roger
Ebert](/wiki/Roger_Ebert "Roger Ebert") of the _[Chicago Sun-
Times](/wiki/Chicago_Sun-Times "Chicago Sun-Times")_ gave the film three stars
and wrote in his review, "There's an audience for this film. It's not me. I
gather younger children will like the breakneck action, the magical ability to
fly and the young hero who has tired of only being a name." Though he did say,
"Their parents and older siblings may find the 89-minute running time quite
long enough."[48]

[Todd McCarthy](/wiki/Todd_McCarthy "Todd McCarthy") of _[The Hollywood
Reporter](/wiki/The_Hollywood_Reporter "The Hollywood Reporter")_ called the
film "a lively but derivative 3D storybook spree for some unlikely action
heroes."[2] Conversely, Justin Chang in _[Variety](/wiki/Variety_\(magazine\)
"Variety \(magazine\)")_ said, "Even tots may emerge feeling slightly
browbeaten by this colorful, strenuous and hyperactive fantasy, which has
moments of charm and beauty but often resembles an exploding toy factory
rather than a work of honest enchantment."[49] [Joe
Morgenstern](/wiki/Joe_Morgenstern "Joe Morgenstern") of _[The Wall Street
Journal](/wiki/The_Wall_Street_Journal "The Wall Street Journal")_ found that
the film "lacks a resonant center," and that the script, "seems to have been
written by committee, with members lobbying for each major character, and the
action, set in vast environments all over the map, spreads itself so thin that
a surfeit of motion vitiates emotion."[50]

### Box
office[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Rise_of_the_Guardians&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Box office")]

_Rise of the Guardians_ grossed $103,412,758 in North America, and
$203,528,912 in other countries, for a worldwide total of $306,941,670.[4]

In North America, the film opened to $32.3 million over its extended five-day
weekend, and with $23.8 million over the three-day weekend, it reached fourth
place behind _[The Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn – Part
2](/wiki/The_Twilight_Saga:_Breaking_Dawn_%E2%80%93_Part_2 "The Twilight Saga:
Breaking Dawn – Part 2")_ , _[Skyfall](/wiki/Skyfall "Skyfall")_ , and
_[Lincoln](/wiki/Lincoln_\(2012_film\) "Lincoln \(2012 film\)")_. The film's
opening was the lowest debut for a DreamWorks Animation film since _[Flushed
Away](/wiki/Flushed_Away "Flushed Away")_.[44] While the film did gross more
than double of its $145 million budget, it still did not turn a profit for
DreamWorks Animation due to its high production and marketing costs, forcing
the studio to take an $83 million [write-
down](/wiki/Revaluation_of_fixed_assets "Revaluation of fixed assets").[51]
This marked the first time that the studio had lost money on an animated film
since _[Sinbad: Legend of the Seven
Seas](/wiki/Sinbad:_Legend_of_the_Seven_Seas "Sinbad: Legend of the Seven
Seas")_.[51][52] As a result of this combined with other factors, in February
2013, the studio announced it was laying off 350 employees as part of a
company-wide restructuring.[52]

## Video
game[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Rise_of_the_Guardians&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: Video game")]

Main article: [Rise of the Guardians: The Video
Game](/wiki/Rise_of_the_Guardians:_The_Video_Game "Rise of the Guardians: The
Video Game")

A video game based on the film was released by [D3
Publisher](/wiki/D3_Publisher "D3 Publisher") on November 20, 2012 in North
America,[63] and released on November 23, 2012 in Europe.[64] It allows gamers
to lead the Guardians in their battle against Pitch. The game is a 3D beat-em-
up, where the player travels through each of the worlds: Burgess, North Pole,
Bunnymund Valley, Tooth Palace, and Sandman's Ship, to fight Pitch's army of
Nightmares. The player can switch between all five guardians at any time, and
freely customize their powers, and they learn new special abilities as they
level up. All the game versions support up to 4-player gameplay.[65] It is
available on the [Wii](/wiki/Wii "Wii"), [Wii U](/wiki/Wii_U "Wii U"), [Xbox
360](/wiki/Xbox_360 "Xbox 360"), [PlayStation 3](/wiki/PlayStation_3
"PlayStation 3"), [Nintendo DS](/wiki/Nintendo_DS "Nintendo DS"), and
[Nintendo 3DS](/wiki/Nintendo_3DS "Nintendo 3DS").[66]

## Possible
sequel[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Rise_of_the_Guardians&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: Possible sequel")]

After the release of the film, the creators of _Rise of the Guardians_
expressed hope that the strong A- Cinemascore average for the film and an
enthusiastic word-of-mouth would gather support for the "chance to make a
sequel or two."[67] Author and co-producer of the series, William Joyce, also
mentioned in March 2013 that he was still in talks about a sequel with
DreamWorks Animation: "There is something that we are proposing that we hope
they will want to do."[68]
